conclusion: The distance between two objects is determined by the difference in the areas under their respective velocity-time graphs.
From the graph, the area under the graph of Object A from 0 to t1 is less than the area under the graph of Object B from 0 to t1.
At t1, Object B is farther ahead of Object A.
From t1 to t2, the area under the graph of Object A is greater than the area under the graph of Object B.
During t1 to t2, Object A is catching up to Object B.
At t2, the area under the graph of Object A is equal to the area under the graph of Object B.
At t2, Object A and Object B are at the same location.
From t2 to t3, the area under the graph of Object A is less than the area under the graph of Object B.
During t2 to t3, Object B is pulling away from Object A.
At t3, the area under the graph of Object A is less than the area under the graph of Object B.
At t3, Object B is farther ahead of Object A.
From t3 to t4, the area under the graph of Object A is greater than the area under the graph of Object B.
During t3 to t4, Object A is catching up to Object B.
At t4, the area under the graph of Object A is equal to the area under the graph of Object B.
At t4, Object A and Object B are at the same location.
The two objects are farthest apart at t3.
